ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to think critically about long-form journalistic writing, especially the kinds of essays published in the New Yorker and the Atlantic. I also learned how to apply various techniques to my own essay writing.
I have learned more about how to write for an audience.

We read and discussed some of the most famous pieces about ideas. I learned less about how to report stories than I did how to approach them and think about framing subjects that are ideas. Solid class. Really interesting readings, great professor, and fun assignments.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: Our class was very small and close-knit (about seven people), so we all had plenty of time in the two-hour seminar to ask questions and share our insights. The readings are also a strength--thought-provoking and intellectually challenging pieces. Weaknesses: The professor often posted readings 1 day before class, not giving us much time to prepare. He also cold-calls students.
The strength of this course was the readings. They were all incredibly engaging and they offered insights that I now see in my own life. I don't recall there being any weaknesses.

The class is very interesting and fun. Prof. Surowiecki is great, too. Sometimes a little disorganized. For example, we got feedback on our first two papers pretty late in the semester and the readings were posted a day or two before class but he is really cool and this class was edifying nonetheless.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)

Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you're interested specifically in reading and learning how to write the kind of pieces you might find in the New Yorker: long-form, intellectual language, American authors, witty, thought-provoking. Not a ton of diversity in terms of types of readings (almost all of them were published in the late 90s and early 00s in a prestigious U.S. publication) but they are pretty fascinating, albeit long.

I would recommend this course to any student interested in journalism or who's interested in learning how to write to inform an audience. Surowiecki offers great feedback, and the readings are fantastic models.
Yes, great course. The majority of people in the class weren't English majors, so definitely apply to this class even if you are a little nervous about it.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
